title: 104_hr1579
content: The Act titled "Sarah Weber Home Infusion Consumer Protection Act of 1995" mandates licensing for providers of home infusion therapy services. The Sarah Weber Home Infusion Consumer Protection Act of 1995 requires licensing for providers of home infusion therapy services in accordance with specific standards set by the state. Individual providers offering these services without compensation are exempt from this requirement. The Sarah Weber Home Infusion Consumer Protection Act of 1995 mandates licensing for home infusion therapy service providers based on set standards by the Secretary of Health and Human Services. Providers must be licensed and capable of offering these services under physician supervision and care plans. The Sarah Weber Home Infusion Consumer Protection Act of 1995 requires licensed providers to offer home infusion therapy services under physician supervision. Providers must maintain clinical records, adhere to protocols, offer services 24/7, coordinate with physicians, conduct quality assessments, and ensure trained staff. The Sarah Weber Home Infusion Consumer Protection Act of 1995 mandates that providers ensure trained personnel deliver infusion products and services, take responsibility for service quality, establish clear protocols, be certified as a home health agency, and meet additional requirements set by the Secretary for patient safety. The Sarah Weber Home Infusion Consumer Protection Act of 1995 requires providers to ensure safe and effective home infusion therapy services, establish protocols for notification of service cancellations, and enforce penalties for violations. The Sarah Weber Home Infusion Consumer Protection Act of 1995 mandates providers to ensure safe home infusion therapy services and enforce penalties for violations. The Secretary will determine State compliance with licensing requirements and may provide grants for establishing the necessary licensing system. Authorization of appropriations is provided for the Secretary to carry out the Act. The Act allows states to charge licensing fees to providers for reimbursement of operating costs. SEC. 3. LIMITATION ON PHYSICIAN REFERRALS. SEC. 3. LIMITATION ON PHYSICIAN REFERRALS. If a physician has a financial relationship with an entity described in the Social Security Act, they cannot refer for home infusion therapy services. Medicare Physician Ownership and Referral Provisions apply to this restriction. The prescription of a drug for home infusion is considered a referral by a referring physician under subsection (b) and section 1877(h)(5) of the Social Security Act. The term "home infusion therapy services" includes nursing, pharmacy, and related services for administering therapeutic agents to patients at home. This Act also calls for a study on Medicare coverage of certain infusion therapy services. The Secretary will conduct a study on the feasibility and economic impact of covering infusion therapy services at home under Medicare Part B. A report with recommendations will be submitted to Congress within one year of the enactment of this Act. A report with recommendations will be submitted to Congress within one year of the enactment of this Act. Regarding licensing requirements for home infusion therapy services, Section 2(a) will apply after 90 days from the enactment date, except in states requiring specific legislation for licensing. The Act specifies that the first calendar quarter after the State legislature's regular session is the reference point. For states with a 2-year session, each year is considered a separate session. Section 3 limitations apply to referrals made after December 31, 1995.
